posts.name:
Sarah Kamalüå∏
Sarah Kamalüå∏
posts.content:
You don't like the life you have ,
You don't like how people treat you,
You don't like the schedule you are enclosed in,
You don't like how things currently are,
You know what,

You have the power to change it.

And let me tell you something more,
It is not at all going to be easy.

Infact it might even shake your entire world in the most undesirable ways.

But even the darkest nights end.

And you are not alone in this,
Not at all.

Here is a few things that helps in getting a clarity,
1. Note down all the problems in your current life, in point form. Be detailed.
2. Follow these points by the causes that has lead to these problems. Take your time think it through.

You realize what just happened, you are able to pin point the exact reasons why you feel stuck in your life.

Once you identify the problem, half the battle is won.

3. Let's think about now actionable steps you can take to change this situation.

Categorize these steps as following,
-Mindset shifts
-Day to Day activities that changes your current scenario
-Long term activities
-Set of small achievable deadlines.

Remember the change does not have to big but,
Nothing changes if you don't change.

12 months can change everything, absolutely everything, let 2025 be that one..

comments.commentText: Sarah, your message is a powerful reminder of the agency we hold in our own lives. Acknowledging the discomfort can indeed be the first step toward meaningful transformation. Your structured approach to identifying issues and envisioning actionable steps is incredibly insightful. Here's to embracing the journey of change, no matter how challenging it may be. Thank you for inspiring us to take control of our destinies.

posts.name:
Jason Feifer
Jason Feifer
posts.content:
This book-design video got 5.7 million views ‚Äî by following this TIMELESS RULE of social media:

Your ORDINARY is someone else‚Äôs EXTRAORDINARY.

People often overthink their social media content, believing they need to be zany or elaborate.

You don‚Äôt. Behind-the-scenes content works amazingly ‚Äî because no matter what you do, SOMEONE is curious how it‚Äôs done.

For example: This is a video from, a book designer for Penguin Press (on IG @ez.bookdesign).

His videos are all like this, showing his design process. Now he has 474,000 followers on IG.

Ask yourself: "What part of my process is most visual?" Could be anything. Shipping boxes. Manufacturing. Lawn care. Travel for meetings. Whatever!

When people SEE your work, they TRUST your work ‚Äî and they want to work with YOU.

If this post was helpful, please share it and followfor more.

 Join 60K readers who get my tips and tactics weekly ‚Äî I share small ways to achieve major professional breakthroughs:

This is a great video.
Authentic and valuable content is what stands out.

posts.content:
Stop and think about this statement.

It's counterintuitive to human nature.

It's a learned communication skill.

Train yourself to ask good questions.

Asking a question puts you in control.

 It's a proactive action.

 Answering a question is a reactive action.

Do you have 4-5 questions that you ask during every discovery call?

posts.name:
Mike Leber
Mike Leber
posts.content:
Companies Push Back Against Remote Work

But where you work is not the question:

These 16 traits set top-performing organizations apart:

1. They value trust over control.
‚Ü≥ Micromanagement kills morale. Trust sparks innovation.

2. They value outcomes, not hours.
‚Ü≥ Results matter more than a 9-to-5 routine.

3. They listen to employees‚Äô needs.
‚Ü≥ Engaged teams outperform pressured ones.

4. They protect deep work.
‚Ü≥ Meaningful work happens when interruptions are minimized.

5. They encourage autonomy.
‚Ü≥ Freedom to work your way drives accountability and creativity.

6. They prioritize collaboration over surveillance.
‚Ü≥ Teams thrive with connection, not constant monitoring.

7. They hire for trust and culture fit.
‚Ü≥ Great teams don‚Äôt need to be babysat - they‚Äôre aligned on values.

8. They adapt, not enforce rigid policies.
‚Ü≥ Flexibility attracts top talent and retains them.

9. They support hybrid models when needed.
‚Ü≥ The right mix of in-office and remote boosts connection and productivity.

10. They invest in meaningful communication tools.
‚Ü≥ Slack, Zoom, and async updates beat endless in-person meetings.

11. They align on purpose, not location.
‚Ü≥ Shared goals create unity, regardless of geography.

12. They see remote work as a skill, not a perk.
‚Ü≥ It‚Äôs about mastering focus and self-management.

13. They reward outcomes, not presenteeism.
‚Ü≥ Showing up doesn‚Äôt equal productivity. Delivering results does.

14. They address struggles with support, not suspicion.
‚Ü≥ Struggling employees need clarity and guidance - not blame.

15. They equip leaders to manage remotely.
‚Ü≥ Great managers lead teams, not desks.

16. They measure engagement, not office attendance.
‚Ü≥ Happy, motivated employees stay, wherever they work.

This isn‚Äôt about remote work!

It‚Äôs about trust, autonomy, and outcomes.

The future belongs to companies that treat their people like pros.

Which of these traits resonates with you the most?
Let me know below ‚¨áÔ∏è

posts.name:
Taylor Scher
Taylor Scher
posts.content:
Right now, these pages have a ton of potential for visibility. 

I called this out a while ago, but I had a feeling AI would make link building significantly easier.

And so far, that's exactly what I'm seeing in GA4.

The majority of the traffic coming from Perplexity and ChatGPT is going directly to my statistics articles.

And I've noticed these pages gaining traction with earning links recently too.

But there's a reason why these pages work so well.

The user doesn't have to click link to link to find the data they're looking for anymore.

They can use the search feature in ChatGPT to find extremely specific statistics that are then generated and cited for them to use directly in their content.

There are issues with ChatGPT citing 404 pages (I've even seen this firsthand), but most times, the cited source seems to be relevant.

Not only am I getting the benefit from having these pages rank from traditional SEO, but I'm now getting additional visibility from AI overviews, ChatGPT, and Perplexity.

I now have way more reach and opportunities for earning links.

If you can nail these pages down and blend them with first-party data, you'll make link building that much easier for you.

It's a huge missed opportunity to not create these pages.

posts.name:
Jeff Rosset
Jeff Rosset
posts.content:
If there were specific profile types of entrepreneurs I‚Äôd likely fall into the ‚ÄúMile a Minute Mike‚Äù or ‚ÄúIdea Factory Ivan‚Äù persona. 

It‚Äôs hard for me to go slow and methodical, and focus on just one or two things.

can confirm.

But when it comes to our product offerings, as painful at times as it‚Äôs been, going slow has worked.

For years we only offered one thing for clients to buy: a membership for unlimited year-round training for your team of ICs

But more and more we heard from our ICP the need for resources for their front-line managers (FLMs). Because as we all know, effective managers are often the key to effective teams, and increased revenue capacity.

In early 2024 we set out to solve the problem we kept hearing about: lack of enablement and insufficient resources for FLMs.

This was to be our first ever second offering. And the transition from a single product to multi SKU business is not easy. Many before us have failed here.

We wanted to get it right.

Lots of market research, Ô∏è
Surveys of current clients and prospects Ô∏è
Evaluated a number of possible partners Ô∏è
Painstakingly methodical approach to the build Ô∏è
Very defined product marketing and comms plan Ô∏è
Every detail accounted for Ô∏è
Collaborative team effort Ô∏è

Fast forward to November, we were finally ready to announce it. Months in the making, our newly built cohort-based Revenue Manager Lab for FLMs was a thing.

The first cohort is set to kick off on 2/20/25, and today, over a month out, were 90% full and anticipate being completely at capacity early next week and needing to close off registrations.

We appear to have nailed what the market was looking for in regards to this problem. And we rolled it out and marketed it in the right way.

The old saying ‚Äúslow is smooth and smooth is fast‚Äù could not be more relevant here

Product development is hard. Can‚Äôt rush it.

posts.name:
Christina Langdon - Success Coach
Christina Langdon - Success Coach
posts.content:
I have an impossible goal for 2025, and I want to share the questions I answered to create it. 

Sometimes, I think I should call myself the Possibilities Coach. I've studied the science of impossible goal setting and believe in my heart that every wild, impossible goal is hidden behind false assumptions of what we believe to be true.

Last week, I gave my Impossible Possibilities workshop to members of The Upside; this question generated the most energy among nearly 70 members.

What are the characteristics and qualities of the person who could achieve your impossible goal?

When you match the process of believing in your impossibility with IDC (Intentional, Discipline, Consistency) you, your team and your organization can achieve the impossible.

Musk, Bezos, and Oprah are no different than you or me - they imagined an impossible goal, built belief, and took massive action.

The Four Step Process:
- Define your impossible goal ‚Äì something that scares you but excites you even more
- Question your basic assumptions about who you serve, how you operate, and what defines success
- Identify the person you need to become to achieve this goal
- Find the "WHOs" ‚Äì the people who can help make your impossible possible
- Commit to taking bold action, even when (especially when) failure feels likely

At, we go deep into the process to reverse engineer goal setting and success with teams and talent. Setting impossible goals is a process of unlocking awareness (around assumptions and the past) and allowing for inspired thinking for a better way forward. If you want to learn more about the process or want to host a team workshop to create the impossible goal, please shoot us a DM.

[Thanks tofor attending the workshop and creating this image of the process!]
